comments.commentBody: While we look at life through the lens of our own experience and culture, it is important to understand the differences that define each of us.  It can be unnerving peering into the soul of poverty and hardship, it is moving too - seeing the grit it takes to get through life in circumstances that don't make living easy.  Where some see lack of responsibility, I see tenacity in the face of adversity. I know in my soul that this family would do whatever they could for neighbor and friend - while having so very little themselves.

To throw stones is easy, to truly understand is unlikely. The divide between rich and poor falls decisively along educational and societal lines, this divide has grown wider and continues to grow at a faster rate as the economic direction of the country accelerates into a technical and trade based economy. The greatest shift in personal wealth from the many to the few has taken place in the last thirty years in an ever increasingly technical society and the change in economic policies favoring the wealthy.
This is just a small example of those left behind by failed educational policies and a culture that does not understand the monumental shift taking place. While the right focuses on "culture wars" fomented by they're wealthy backers as a distraction from reality and the left fumbles rudderless and clueless in the face of adversity the country suffers from a lack of will to take on the difficult core issues that plague us, and will for years to come.
These people are the ones on the outside looking in with no clue as to where to start or how, they are just a small sampling of the permanent underclass we have created. Don't excoriate them for not possessing the skills and ability to climb out of the cycle of poverty they exist in when the tools and education to do so were never offered.
If you started miles behind the poverty line, even getting to it is a difficult and daunting task, it takes generations to exceed it, then once on the ground floor real progress can be made. Education is the future, period, if we don't offer it to the widest segment of society in equal amounts we will be strangling our own future. Throwing stones at these families is like trying to make ourselves feel powerful by beating a person half our size, it's a hollow and shallow response to a growing problem.
I speak from experience, I have worked my way from poverty to a very comfortable existence, one where I too have reached the level of income favored by the current finance and tax laws. Unfortunately I find many of my contemporaries spending too much energy attempting to keep others from attaining those same milestones, in the end it only hurts us all. What kind of society have we become? Is it one we can feel truly proud of?
True humanity requires humility, a quality that seems out of place these days.

The Reds said that the Finns might cut off Lennigrad in the case of war with Germany,so that gave them the right to attack the Finns who ended up massacring 100,000 Russians before being over whelmed. Even though the Finns went back to war with the Russians in 1941,they never closed the ice causeway to Lennigrad anyway and all those Reds died for squat. We only took 30,000 casualities for keeping Saadam from using weapons he didn`t have. The untold butchery that the Iraqi people did to each other will rival Pol Pot`s atrocities in Cambodia. We are not responsible for that because the Iraqis should have welcomed us as liberators and adopted supply side economics instead of turning 13 pent up centuries of hatred loose. We are not responsible because our intentions wer good, well sort of good. History will assure that the world to come knows two things about us. We fueled the slave trade that de-populated Western Africa to the tune of maybe 40,000,000 and we created a human buchery machine in the land that Abraham left 3500 years ago that swallowed up a generation of Iraqi kids. A New dawn alright; however there will be no New dawns for them, ever.
Charles B. Tiffany
Kissimmee, Florida.

To arnold at post number 25:

I think an open-ended war is one in which NO objective is established--or one in which the objective is one upon which no reasonable metric for measurement exists.

If you can articulate a cogent objective to be accomplished in Afghanistan---the achievement of which will be recognizable and upon recognition, will signal the end of the war--then by all means, have at it. An anxious and cash-strapped nation--tired of seeing the blood of of young men and women spilled in order to prop up a corrupt mayor and a bunch of narco-terrorists--would love to hear.

Seriously, my friend, that days when we could look forward to surrender ceremonies on the deck of a battleship are long gone.

We went into Afghanistan--ostensibly to capture Bin Laden and his lieutenants, to take down a brutal regime that was harboring him--and to demonstrate to the world that there is no safe haven for those who would attempt to terrorize Americans.

Am I missing something there?

It seems to me we've accomplished two out of the three items on that list--and the first one we screwed the pooch on early on--when we decided to outsource the smoke'em out effort at Tora-Bora--and let Osama & Co skeedaddle across the border into Pakistan.

It is so easy and glib to look at others through our citified lenses! If you haven't lived through repeated hurricanes as I have, if you haven't smelled the salty fear in the gales, if you haven't lived through the constant thunderous drumming of wind on the shelter you're in, then keep you're better-than-you snideness to yourself. The consequent dullness of feeling when you're a survivor is not the TV scary 'survivor' stuff and filmed bravado. When water and shelter are the most you expect in such events, then you don't mind of an insect made it through the day'n'night with you and your neighbors.
Poverty is far less contagious than arrogance and loss of compassion for others.

The truth is that there is no alternative to peace. The status quo is just not sustainable in the long run and becomes less stable with each passing year.

The nuclear genie can not be contained forever. Only a comprehensive/genuine peace will resolve the conflicts here. Ongoing violence will only worsen them. On one level this is not such a complex equation.

The only parties who benefit from a continuation of the status quo are the extremist fanatics on all sides, local pols who profit from conflict and arms manufacturers.

Now is the time to settle this......it will never be easier than it is now. Failure to achieve peace will, eventually, lead to a conflagration that destroys the quality of life for the whole region...with no exceptions. No one "wins" that war.

Wow! Unbelievably negative comments for most of at least the first 50 with the exception of Anne #19. What cynical spinelessness to rant that because so many past attempts have failed to bring peace between the Palestinians and the Israelis then all attempts will fail. These comments feed into exactly what those who hate the idea of peace between Arab and Israeli, the West and the East, the Black and the White, etc., of the world want, expect and need to continue their manipulation of all societies interested in peace between the varied peoples of this world. Who believe in diversity of thought and freedom to choose.

I suggest those who say there cannot be peace because of previous events should let the Palestinians and the Israelis decide as two peoples, not as this or that individual, if peace can be achieved. I say they can do it, and yes, they do need the help and support of others in the region and outside to do it. Thankfully there is the willingness of those in power in the United States, Britain, Jordan, Egypt the EU and many others to try and make this a reality, to help. And thankfully, I believe, the collective people of these countries do as well, regardless of hate driven groups, and individuals like those who's fatalistic self serving negative comments have been submitted so far.

It is difficult to discuss the Middle East without giving voice to our cynicism. Often I would have joined the most cynical commenters here. These maddening negotiations have failed the world again and again. But, we still must try to turn the cynicism off.

Netanyahu and Abbas may not seem capable of achieving peace, but it must happen. There is no lasting peace for anyone in the Middle East and no demographic future for a Jewish Israel without it. And, now that we are engaged in Middle Eastern combat, we can not disengage until this peace is in effect. We will remain at war until this peace works.

This is the Middle East and these negotiations will succeed when they have to. Not when we wished they would. Not when we wanted them. Not when we demanded them. Not even when we needed them to succeed. But, we are close to the time when they will have to work. The alternatives are becoming unthinkable and they are approaching.

I've been a news junkie, since I was a kid and I've been ringside at this fight for nearly half a century. I've cheered and booed both sides and I've watched as an apolitical cynic. Something is happening that I've never seen before and it does't have a neat description.

It's more of a feeling that things that must happen for peace must happen now or very soon or they will never happen. I am not alone in feeling that the place is here, the time is now and there won't be a later.

When peace is made, it's usually made by weak flawed men who rise above themselves for the good of their people. Even then they must be forced to face themselves by strife and time and disillusion. We should pray in any religion we hold dear that Netanyahu and Abbas are the weak flawed men that will do this for us all. They will both have to yeild on many more points that will put their careers and lives in danger.

While hope still lives , we should try not to bring our hatreds and cynicism to this peace table. It's a waste of time. The table is overflowing with both.
